timeline.bodyText: Does the spec call it CollectionGeometry, or is this just your choice? GeometryCollection would make more sense otherwise?
timeline.author: JonathanGiles

replies.bodyText: Also, is it weird to anyone else that a CollectionGeometry is a Geometry?
replies.author: JonathanGiles

replies.bodyText: It is a bit weird but it follows in the definition of the RFC. https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc7946#section-3
replies.author: alzimmermsft

replies.bodyText: Ok - but you'll rename this to GeometryCollection?
replies.author: JonathanGiles

replies.bodyText: I think I'm going to keep the name as is for the reason that all other Geometry sub types are using the naming pattern <Type>Geometry (PointGeometry, PolygonGeometry). Switching this to GeometryCollection would cause it to be the only one which goes against that pattern.
replies.author: alzimmermsft

timeline.bodyText: Collection isn't the most useful type in Java - should we do something more useful, such as List or Set?
timeline.author: JonathanGiles
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,43 @@

+package com.azure.core.spatial;
+

+import java.util.Collections;
+
+/**
+ * Represents a heterogeneous collection of {@link Geometry geometries}.
+ */
+public final class CollectionGeometry extends Geometry {
+    private final Collection<Geometry> geometries;
+
+    /**
+     * Constructs a geometry collection.
+     *
+     * @param geometries The geometries in the collection.
+     */
+    public CollectionGeometry(Collection<Geometry> geometries) {

replies.bodyText: I'll change this to a list.
replies.author: alzimmermsft

timeline.bodyText: Should there be validation on these values?
timeline.author: JonathanGiles
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,103 @@
+// Copyright (c) Microsoft Corporation. All rights reserved.
+// Licensed under the MIT License.
+
+package com.azure.core.spatial;
+
+/**
+ * Represents a geometric bounding box.
+ */
+public final class GeometryBoundingBox {
+    private final double west;
+    private final double south;
+    private final double east;
+    private final double north;
+
+    private final Double minAltitude;
+    private final Double maxAltitude;
+
+    /**
+     * Constructs a bounding box.
+     *
+     * @param west West longitudinal boundary.
+     * @param south South latitudinal boundary.
+     * @param east East longitudinal boundary.
+     * @param north North latitudinal boundary.
+     */
+    public GeometryBoundingBox(double west, double south, double east, double north) {
+        this(west, south, east, north, null, null);
+    }
+
+    /**
+     * Constructs a bounding box.
+     *
+     * @param west West longitudinal boundary.
+     * @param south South latitudinal boundary.
+     * @param east East longitudinal boundary.
+     * @param north North latitudinal boundary.
+     * @param minAltitude Minimum altitude boundary.
+     * @param maxAltitude Maximum altitude boundary.
+     */
+    public GeometryBoundingBox(double west, double south, double east, double north, Double minAltitude,
+        Double maxAltitude) {

replies.bodyText: Could be, west/east are longitudes which should be between +/- 180, south/north are latitudes which should be between +/- 90.
replies.author: alzimmermsft

replies.bodyText: I wouldn't do any extra validation here. These values can be in meters too. We should keep these object as much of DTOs as possible and let services to the validation.
replies.author: pakrym

replies.bodyText: This raises the question on whether we should validate additional constructors as well. For example a polygon type the first and last point in its points need to be the same coordinate, crossing the anti-meridian requires changing type (line to multi-line). The other option is keeping validation localized to simple scenarios such as this.
replies.author: alzimmermsft

replies.bodyText: I avoided any validation all together, send whatever customer puts into the object and exposed whatever service returned. We don't implement any operations on geometries on the client side so we don't care about data being valid in any way.
replies.author: pakrym

timeline.bodyText: I understand why you have Double type in these places, but I'm not super fond of it. I would wonder if we should have a boolean check that clarifies if it has been set or not.
timeline.author: JonathanGiles

replies.bodyText: I can add APIs such hasAltitude, hasMinAltitude, hasMaxAltitude for the scenarios where we have null-able geoposition data. Do you feel that these add enough benefit for having additional APIs?
replies.author: alzimmermsft

timeline.bodyText: Do you think, rather than have all Geometry subclasses having a getProperties() method, that Geometry itself should just contain the content of the GeometryProperties class? It seems quite long-winded to get a property at present, because you firstly need to getProperties.
timeline.author: JonathanGiles

replies.bodyText: Based on the RFC geometry is a concept which is a set of positions and optional bounding box and additional properties, so having this be in a superclass makes sense based on the definition. I could see removing GeometryProperties for its direct types of bounding box and additional properties, flattening the structure by a level.
replies.author: alzimmermsft

timeline.bodyText: Is there a need for this ctor to be public - it seems like no sane user would need to call this? Also, should there be a ctor that takes just the bounding box?
timeline.author: JonathanGiles

replies.bodyText: It is better to use setter pattern in this class. Search is only asking additional properties.
replies.author: sima-zhu

replies.bodyText: I'm thinking of removing this class and using its components directly in Geometry.
replies.author: alzimmermsft

replies.bodyText: Removed GeometryProperties.
replies.author: alzimmermsft

timeline.bodyText: Should you make a copy of this map so that it can not be mutated after being set?
timeline.author: JonathanGiles

replies.bodyText: Making a deep copy now.
replies.author: alzimmermsft

timeline.bodyText: Make a defensive copy in the ctor rather than here, otherwise the positions can be changed by the user having a reference to the positions collection that they gave to you.
timeline.author: JonathanGiles

replies.bodyText: Adding defensive copies of the list in the constructor, also making the store list unmodifiable at the same time.
replies.author: alzimmermsft

timeline.bodyText: Don't forget to export through modules-info too
timeline.author: JonathanGiles

timeline.bodyText: Search use-case does not use altitude. So for serialization, this field is not required. Make sure the serializer will remove the field once it is null. Or make it optional.
timeline.author: sima-zhu

replies.bodyText: Since it is a Double it is optional, if it is set it will be included in the serialization. I don't know what the Search service will do if it is included though.
replies.author: alzimmermsft

replies.bodyText:
There is a slightly chance to go wrong.
If sdk set the JsonInclude (JsonInclude(Include.ALWAYS)), then the serializer will include the field set to null.
Also, I am curious how would it be like for serialization.
Here is what search looks like:
"type":"Point","coordinates":[-122.131577,47.678581]
replies.author: sima-zhu

replies.bodyText: We'd better to assume service will throw error if you provide something unwanted in core spatial.
replies.author: sima-zhu

replies.bodyText: To make my point clear, if we set 'altitude' anyway in constructor, in some cases, we send out altitude even it sets to null.  (e.g. use JsonInclude(Include.ALWAYS)). So it is better to remove final and have setter to set the optional field.
replies.author: sima-zhu

replies.bodyText: These classes will be using a custom serializer and deserializer handler in Azure Core which won't include altitude if it is null. I've added them in the last commit.
replies.author: alzimmermsft

replies.bodyText: Just saw the commit. That solves the problem. Thanks!
replies.author: sima-zhu

timeline.bodyText: Does search need to provide specific serializer/deserializer for coordinate system?
timeline.author: sima-zhu

timeline.bodyText:
I was wondering if this could be named differently or to be more specific into the spatial concept that we would foresee it being used. Or do we want this same model to be more generic and allow including the concept of the BoundingBox we encountered in FormRecognizer here.
Where a BoundingBox could be a "Quadrangle bounding box, with coordinates specified relative to the top-left of the original image. The eight numbers represent the four points, clockwise from the top-left corner relative to the text orientation. For image, the (x, y) coordinates are measured in pixels. For PDF, the (x, y) coordinates are measured in inches.",
timeline.author: samvaity

replies.bodyText: I believe these concepts are distinct from each other. The GeoJSON bounding box must be a rectangle as it simply lists to left, right, top, bottom bounding areas, with optional depth. Form Recognizer uses the four corners of the bounding area so it is a quadrangle which is a super set from a rectangle.
replies.author: alzimmermsft

replies.bodyText:
I think it's fair to keep them as two separate models especially considering the fact that FR service is thinking of updating the BoundingBox to not be restricted to just four points and it can then grow differently.
But still think that GeometryBoundaryBox model name is too generic and can confuse users once we start including the other BoundingBox concepts. It doesn't suggest it is a GeoJson bounding box.  What do you think?
replies.author: samvaity

replies.bodyText:
That's a good thought.
@pakrym, @srnagar, @JonathanGiles, @KrzysztofCwalina, ideas here as this will be common across the languages
replies.author: alzimmermsft

replies.bodyText: I'm ok with how it is named now, but I am open to suggestions for other names too.
replies.author: JonathanGiles

replies.bodyText: To me the prefix seems reasonable to distinguish.
replies.author: pakrym

timeline.bodyText: We encountered situations in user studies where users seem to be wanting a toString() method on the returned models. I am considering adding those in FormRecognizer, do we think we should consider that here too?
timeline.author: samvaity

replies.bodyText: Could be done, I was thinking it could be their GeoJSON representation.
replies.author: alzimmermsft

timeline.bodyText: Is it worth the performance cost to copy the source list into a new array list?
timeline.author: srnagar
